title: ZLA: High-Altitude Reroute and Conflict
description: Handle a high-altitude reroute due to pop-up weather and resolve crossing traffic.

steps.description: UAL123 (FL350) reports moderate turbulence and requests deviation 30 miles right of track. Sector is busy.

options.text: Acknowledge request. "UAL123, deviation 30 miles right of track approved, report when able direct original route."
options.feedback: Partial. This approval is too permissive without checking for traffic. A restriction is needed.

options.text: Approve deviation and issue restriction. "UAL123, deviation 30 miles right of track approved, maintain FL350. Report when able to resume routing."
options.feedback: Correct. This approves the deviation while ensuring altitude compliance, which is critical for the next step.

options.text: Deny request. "UAL123, unable deviation, maintain track."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Denying a weather deviation without cause is unsafe.

options.text: Issue turn only. "UAL123, fly heading 190, vectors for weather."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is less efficient than a pilot-retained deviation and uses non-standard phraseology for this context.

steps.description: You observe UAL123's new track will conflict with AAL456 (FL360) in 8 minutes. AAL456 is opposite direction.

options.text: Issue descent. "UAL123, descend and maintain FL330."
options.feedback: Correct. This provides immediate vertical separation from the FL360 traffic and is the most efficient resolution.

options.text: Issue climb. "UAL123, climb and maintain FL370."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This would bust the adjacent sector's altitude stratum without coordination.

options.text: Issue vector. "UAL123, turn left heading 150."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This turns them back into the weather they are avoiding.

options.text: Wait to see if the pilot corrects.
options.feedback: Incorrect. Waiting ensures a loss of separation.

steps.description: UAL123 is now at FL330. The pilot reports clear of weather and requests to resume original route and altitude.

options.text: Approve immediately. "UAL123, cleared direct original route, climb and maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is unsafe as the conflict with AAL456 may still exist or another conflict could be created.

options.text: Provide vector. "UAL123, fly heading 180, join J52."
options.feedback: Partial. This is procedurally acceptable but less efficient than 'cleared direct' if the route is clear.

options.text: Verify traffic. "UAL123, standby... (checks traffic)... UAL123, when able, proceed direct PEKUE, resume FL350."
options.feedback: Partial. This is good practice, but 'resume FL350' is not the correct phraseology. A climb clearance is required.

options.text: Verify traffic and clear. "UAL123, when able, proceed direct PEKUE. Climb and maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Correct. This verifies the aircraft's capability, provides an efficient clearance, and re-establishes the correct altitude.

steps.description: UAL123 is re-established on route at FL350, approaching the boundary with ZOA (Oakland Center).

options.text: Initiate data link handoff. "UAL123, contact Oakland Center 135.5."
options.feedback: Correct. Standard procedure for handoff in a data link environment.

options.text: Wait for pilot to report boundary.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is passive control and not standard procedure.

options.text: Tell ZOA to take control. "ZOA, your control UAL123."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This phraseology is for specific, non-standard situations, not routine handoffs.

options.text: Flash UAL123 on ZOA's scope and wait for them to accept.
options.feedback: Partial. This is part of the internal process, but the instruction to the pilot is the key action.

title: ZOB: Reroute and Sequencing (Lake Effect)
description: Manage a high-altitude sector during a significant lake-effect snow event, requiring reroutes around build-ups and sequencing for KDTW.

steps.description: Massive weather cell (lake effect) is blocking the YNG1 arrival into KDTW. SWA445 (FL370) is 100 miles from the arrival gate.

options.text: Let the pilot deviate as needed. "SWA445, weather depicted ahead, deviate as required."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is too ambiguous and cedes control in a high-density area.

options.text: Proactively reroute. "SWA445, due weather, cleared direct FNT, maintain FL370. Expect YNG1 arrival from FNT."
options.feedback: Partial. This is a good reroute, but it doesn't confirm the new arrival; it just sets an expectation.

options.text: Issue a full reroute clearance. "SWA445, amend route. Cleared direct FNT, direct ROZZY, YNG1 arrival. Maintain FL370."
options.feedback: Correct. This provides a specific, unambiguous, and full reroute clearance to navigate weather and rejoin the arrival.

options.text: Vector the aircraft. "SWA445, fly heading 270, vectors around weather."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Vectoring at this distance is inefficient and increases controller workload.

steps.description: DAL88 (FL350) is 20 miles behind SWA445, same route. You must also reroute them.

options.text: Give the same clearance. "DAL88, amend route. Cleared direct FNT, direct ROZZY, YNG1 arrival. Maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Correct. This maintains consistency and ensures both aircraft are on a known, clear track.

options.text: Descend them. "DAL88, descend and maintain FL290."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a premature descent and doesn't solve the weather problem.

options.text: Tell them to follow SWA445. "DAL88, follow SWA445, cleared same reroute."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Non-standard and imprecise phraseology.

options.text: Issue a speed restriction. "DAL88, reduce speed to Mach point seven eight."
options.feedback: Partial. This might be needed for spacing, but it doesn't address the primary weather reroute issue.

steps.description: SWA445, now on the new route, needs to descend for the arrival. KDTW approach requests they cross ROZZY at FL240.

options.text: Issue descent. "SWA445, descend and maintain FL240."
options.feedback: Partial. This is a valid clearance, but a crossing restriction is more precise and expected in this context.

options.text: Issue pilot's discretion descent. "SWA445, pilot's discretion, maintain FL240."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This gives too much flexibility when sequencing is required.

options.text: Issue crossing restriction. "SWA445, cross ROZZY at and maintain FL240."
options.feedback: Correct. This is standard ICAO phraseology for a crossing restriction and ensures the aircraft meets the arrival profile.

options.text: Issue descent for approach. "SWA445, descend via the YNG1 arrival."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a
clearance and is not appropriate until the aircraft is fully established on the published arrival.

steps.description: DAL88 is now 15 miles behind SWA445. You need to provide a similar descent clearance while maintaining separation.

options.text: Issue same restriction. "DAL88, cross ROZZY at and maintain FL240."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This will compress separation with SWA445, who is also descending to FL240.

options.text: Issue speed control. "DAL88, reduce speed 20 knots, descend and maintain FL250."
options.feedback: Partial. This is a valid separation tactic, but FL250 might not be coordinated.

options.text: Issue a stepped descent. "DAL88, cross 30 miles northeast of ROZZY at and maintain FL260, then cross ROZZY at and maintain FL240."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Overly complex and non-standard.

options.text: Issue a higher crossing restriction. "DAL88, cross ROZZY at and maintain FL250."
options.feedback: Correct. This provides 1000 feet of vertical separation over the fix, ensuring spacing is maintained during the descent phase.

title: Shanwick: CPDLC Altitude Request (NAT-OTS)
description: Manage an in-trail CPDLC altitude change request within the North Atlantic Organized Track System (OTS).

steps.description: BAW213 (FL370) on NAT Track 'Charlie' sends a CPDLC request: 'REQ CLB FL390'. ADS-C data shows same-track traffic, VIR45, is 60 NM ahead at FL370 and AAL109 is 70 NM behind at FL370.

options.text: Send CPDLC response: 'CLB FL390'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is unsafe. Longitudinal separation has not been established with the aircraft ahead (VIR45).

options.text: Send CPDLC response: 'UNABLE FL390 DUE TRAFFIC'.
options.feedback: Partial. This is a safe response, but it's not the only or best option. More information is needed.

options.text: Send CPDLC response: 'STDBY'. Check longitudinal separation with VIR45.
options.feedback: Correct. This acknowledges the request and allows the controller time to verify Mach Number Technique separation.

options.text: Send CPDLC response: 'MAINTAIN FL370'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a rejection, not a pending instruction. 'Standby' is the correct procedure.

steps.description: You check the flight data. BAW213 is M0.82. VIR45 (ahead) is M0.82. AAL109 (behind) is M0.83. The minimum longitudinal separation is 10 minutes.

options.text: BAW213 is gaining on VIR45. Climb is not possible.
options.feedback: Incorrect. They are at the same Mach speed, so separation should be constant.

options.text: AAL109 is gaining on BAW213. Climb is not possible.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The aircraft behind does not prevent the aircraft in front from climbing.

options.text: BAW213 and VIR45 are at the same Mach. Separation is constant and standard. The climb to FL390 is clear of all traffic.
options.feedback: Correct. Standard longitudinal separation (10 minutes) is established and maintained as they are same-Mach. The level above (FL390) is clear.

options.text: AAL109 is faster. You must slow down AAL109 before clearing BAW213 to climb.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is an unnecessary restriction on AAL109.

steps.description: Separation is confirmed. You must now issue the clearance to BAW213.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'CLB FL390'.
options.feedback: Partial. This is missing the crossing condition, which is vital in procedural airspace.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'CLB TO AND MAINTAIN FL390'.
options.feedback: Partial. Same as A. This is a domestic-style clearance and lacks the required procedural constraints.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'AT (current time+5 min) CLB TO AND MAINTAIN FL390'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. A time-based clearance is not required here.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'CLIMB TO AND MAINTAIN FL390, REPORT REACHING'.
options.feedback: Correct. This is the standard ICAO clearance. In a procedural environment, the 'REPORT REACHING' element is critical for the controller's situational awareness.

steps.description: BAW213 sends a CPDLC message: 'WILCO'. Moments later, you receive an ADS-C message 'LEVEL FL390'.

options.text: Send a CPDLC 'ACKNOWLEDGE' to the 'LEVEL FL390' message.
options.feedback: Correct. The controller must acknowledge the level report to close the loop.

options.text: Update the flight strip and do nothing.
options.feedback: Partial. Updating the strip is correct, but the pilot's report must be acknowledged.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'RADAR CONTACT'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is oceanic airspace; there is no radar.

steps.title: Madrid: Oceanic Entry & Military Airspace
steps.description: Manage a westbound aircraft transitioning from European domestic airspace to oceanic, coordinating with Santa Maria (LPPO) via data link, while a military area is active.
IBE612 (FL360) is approaching the boundary with Santa Maria Oceanic (LPPO). The Oceanic Clearance (OCL) has been received via data link: 'CLRD TO KJFK VIA NAT T, FL360, M080, OCL 1/1 1230'.

options.text: No action needed. The OCL is automatic.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The domestic controller must verify the OCL matches the aircraft's current state before transfer.

options.text: Check that the aircraft's current flight level (FL360) and Mach (M0.80) match the OCL before transfer.
options.feedback: Correct. This is the 'Oceanic Clearance Delivery' check. The domestic controller is the last line of defense to ensure the aircraft enters oceanic airspace as cleared.

options.text: Instruct the pilot to contact Santa Maria. "IBE612, contact Santa Maria on 127.9."
options.feedback: Partial. This is the handoff instruction, but it must only be given *after* the OCL check is complete.

options.text: Ask the pilot to read back the full oceanic clearance.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is not required if the clearance was delivered via data link (CPDLC).

steps.description: Just as you verify the OCL, a 'hot' military area (LED10) activates, cutting across IBE612's cleared track to the oceanic entry point (OEP).

options.text: Vector IBE612 around the area. "IBE612, turn right heading 290, vectors to avoid restricted airspace."
options.feedback: Correct. This is the most immediate and positive control action to ensure separation from the new hazard.

options.text: Tell the pilot to deviate. "IBE612, restricted area LED10 active ahead, deviate as required."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is too permissive and unsafe for a restricted area.

options.text: Tell Santa Maria to handle it. (Initiate data link coord) 'LPPO, RE-ROUTE IBE612 DUE LED10'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The aircraft is still in your airspace and your responsibility.

options.text: Let the aircraft continue. The military will see them.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a gross violation of procedure.

steps.description: The vector takes IBE612 off the cleared oceanic track. You must coordinate this change with Santa Maria.

options.text: Re-clear the aircraft. "IBE612, cleared direct [new OEP], maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Partial. You must coordinate this new entry point with Santa Maria *before* issuing the clearance.

options.text: Initiate voice coordination with Santa Maria. "Santa Maria, Madrid. Estimate IBE612 at [new OEP] at 1245, FL360."
options.feedback: Correct. A non-standard route change (vector) requires voice or highly specific data link coordination to ensure the oceanic controller accepts the new track and estimate.

options.text: Handoff the aircraft. "IBE612, contact Santa Maria 127.9."
options.feedback: Incorrect. You cannot handoff an aircraft on a vector and not on a coordinated track.

options.text: Send a 'Current Profile' data link message to Santa Maria.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is too passive and does not confirm acceptance of the new track.

steps.description: Santa Maria accepts the new estimate. IBE612 is now clear of the military area and 20 miles from the new, coordinated OEP.

options.text: Clear the aircraft direct. "IBE612, resume own navigation, cleared direct [new OEP]."
options.feedback: Partial. This is good, but the handoff instruction is missing.

options.text: Give the handoff. "IBE612, contact Santa Maria on 127.9."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The aircraft is still on a vector; they need to be re-established on a route first.

options.text: Re-establish and handoff. "IBE612, proceed direct [new OEP], contact Santa Maria 127.9."
options.feedback: Correct. This clearance re-establishes the aircraft on the coordinated route and immediately transfers them to the next sector.

options.text: Ask pilot to report OEP. "IBE612, report passing [new OEP]."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is unnecessary and delays the handoff.

steps.title: Singapore: Datalink Reroute & FIR Coordination
steps.description: Manage a data link (CPDLC) reroute request for weather, requiring coordination with Kuala Lumpur (WMFC) in a dense traffic environment.
SIA321 (FL380), on a CPDLC connection, sends 'REQ DEVIATION 20NM RIGHT OF TRACK DUE WX'. This deviation will penetrate Kuala Lumpur (WMFC) airspace.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE DEVIATION DUE TRAFFIC'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a premature denial without checking for solutions.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'STDBY'. Initiate data link coordination with WMFC.
options.feedback: Correct. The request must be acknowledged (STDBY) and coordination with the adjacent FIR is mandatory before approval.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'DEVIATION 20NM RIGHT OF TRACK APPROVED'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This violates the airspace of WMFC without coordination.

options.text: Tell the pilot to call on voice. Send CPDLC: 'CONTACT SINGAPORE 132.8'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The goal of data link is to *reduce* voice calls. You should be able to handle this via data link.

steps.description: You send an 'Advance Coordination' (ADC) data link message to WMFC, proposing the deviation. WMFC replies 'ACCEPT'.

options.text: Send CPDLC to SIA321: 'DEVIATION 20NM RIGHT OF TRACK APPROVED'.
options.feedback: Partial. This is the correct approval, but it lacks the critical 'when able' instruction for rejoining the route.

options.text: Send CPDLC to SIA321: 'DEVIATION 20NM RIGHT OF TRACK APPROVED. REPORT WHEN ABLE TO RESUME ROUTING.'
options.feedback: Correct. This is the full, unambiguous clearance, giving the pilot discretion for the deviation and placing the onus on them to report back.

options.text: Send CPDLC to SIA321: 'CLEARED DIRECT [NEXT WPT]'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This doesn't match the pilot's request for a deviation.

options.text: Call SIA321 on voice to give the clearance.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The entire exchange was initiated via data link; it should be completed via data link.

steps.description: While SIA321 is deviating, you spot a potential conflict with MAS65 (FL370) inside WMFC airspace. You are not controlling MAS65.

options.text: Send CPDLC to SIA321: 'IMMEDIATELY DESCEND FL360'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. You cannot control an aircraft in another FIR's airspace (WMFC) without explicit delegation.

options.text: Send CPDLC to SIA321: 'TRAFFIC INFORMATION: MAS65, OPPOSITE DIRECTION, 15 MILES, FL370'.
options.feedback: Correct. You can and should provide traffic information, even across a boundary, to enhance the pilot's situational awareness.

options.text: Send data link message to WMFC: 'REQUEST CONTROL MAS65 FOR SEPARATION'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is overly complex and unnecessary. WMFC is responsible for separating their own traffic.

options.text: Do nothing. It is WMFC's responsibility.
options.feedback: Partial. While technically WMFC's responsibility, providing a traffic advisory is good airmanship and enhances safety.

steps.description: SIA321 sends a CPDLC message: 'RESUMING OWN NAVIGATION DIRECT VPL'. The aircraft is now back on the original route.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'ROGER'.
options.feedback: Partial. 'ROGER' is not standard CPDLC. 'ACKNOWLEDGE' is, but a more formal clearance is better.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'PROCEED DIRECT VPL'.
options.feedback: Correct. This formally re-establishes the aircraft on its cleared route.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'WILCO'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. WILCO (Will Comply) is a pilot response, not a controller instruction.

options.text: Do nothing. The report is sufficient.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The controller must acknowledge the pilot's action and confirm the route.

steps.title: ZLA: Descent and Speed Control
steps.description: Manage a pair of aircraft descending into the LAX arrival gate, requiring altitude and speed restrictions to maintain separation.
AAL23 (FL390) and UAL88 (FL370) are on the same track (J50) inbound to LAX. AAL23 is 15 NM ahead of UAL88. Both are requesting descent via the ANJEL arrival.

options.text: Clear both. "AAL23, descend via the ANJEL THREE arrival." "UAL88, descend via the ANJEL THREE arrival."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This will cause a compression and loss of separation, as AAL23 will descend through UAL88's level.

options.text: Clear AAL23, hold UAL88. "AAL23, descend via the ANJEL THREE arrival." "UAL88, maintain FL370."
options.feedback: Partial. This is safe, but inefficient. UAL88 will be too high.

options.text: Clear AAL23, descend UAL88 with restriction. "AAL23, descend via the ANJEL THREE arrival." "UAL88, descend and maintain FL250."
options.feedback: Partial. This is safer, but still not the most efficient method for maintaining in-trail spacing.

options.text: Clear AAL23, descend UAL88 with speed. "AAL23, descend via the ANJEL THREE arrival." "UAL88, maintain Mach point eight two or greater, descend and maintain FL250."
options.feedback: Correct. This descends UAL88 to a level clear of the arrival, while the speed instruction prevents UAL88 from catching AAL23 during descent.

steps.description: AAL23 (descending through FL290) reports 'Unable speed restrictions on arrival due to turbulence.' They are slowing down.

options.text: Acknowledge. "AAL23, roger."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a passive response to a report that will affect separation.

options.text: Issue speed to UAL88. "UAL88, reduce speed to 280 knots."
options.feedback: Correct. AAL23 is slowing, so you must immediately slow the aircraft behind (UAL88) to maintain longitudinal separation.

options.text: Tell AAL23 to maintain speed. "AAL23, unable, maintain 310 knots."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Denying a pilot's request due to turbulence is unsafe.

options.text: Vector UAL88. "UAL88, turn left heading 240."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Vectoring is a premature and inefficient solution.

steps.description: Your speed restriction on UAL88 is working. AAL23 is passing FL210. UAL88 is now at FL250, 12 NM behind AAL23.

options.text: Descend UAL88. "UAL88, descend via the ANJEL THREE arrival."
options.feedback: Correct. The lead aircraft (AAL23) is well below UAL88's level, and separation is stable. UAL88 can now be given the arrival.

options.text: Keep UAL88 high. "UAL88, maintain FL250."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is inefficient and will deliver the aircraft to approach control too high.

options.text: Issue a further speed reduction. "UAL88, reduce speed to 250 knots."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is unnecessary as separation is already stable.

options.text: Vector UAL88 for spacing. "UAL88, fly heading 270 for spacing."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The in-trail spacing is acceptable; a vector is not needed.

steps.description: Both aircraft are descending on the arrival and approaching the handoff boundary with SoCal Approach (SCT).

options.text: Handoff AAL23 first. "AAL23, contact SoCal Approach 134.2."
options.feedback: Correct. Handoff the lead aircraft first, then the trailing aircraft, maintaining the sequence.

options.text: Handoff UAL88 first. "UAL88, contact SoCal Approach 134.2."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is out of sequence and confusing.

options.text: Handoff both at once. "AAL23 and UAL88, contact SoCal Approach 134.2."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This can lead to simultaneous radio calls (garbling) and is poor procedure.

options.text: Wait for both to be at FL190.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The handoff should occur at the designated boundary or altitude, not an arbitrary one.

steps.title: ZOB: Crossing Traffic & Altitude Amendment
steps.description: Resolve a crossing traffic conflict between an international arrival and a domestic overflight.
LUF438 (FL350) is inbound from Europe, level at FL350. AAL112 (FL340) is climbing to FL360 on a crossing track. Conflict in 6 minutes.

options.text: Let AAL112 continue climbing. "AAL112, climb and maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This will cause AAL112 to climb directly through LUF438's altitude.

options.text: Stop AAL112's climb. "AAL112, maintain FL340."
options.feedback: Partial. This is safe, but 'STOP CLIMB' is non-standard. 'MAINTAIN' is correct, but it may be too late.

options.text: Stop AAL112's climb with a reason. "AAL112, stop climb FL340, traffic LUF438, 11 o'clock, 20 miles, FL350."
options.feedback: Correct. This uses standard phraseology ('stop climb' is non-standard, but 'maintain FL340' would also work if they hadn't passed it). Issuing 'MAINTAIN FL340' immediately is the best action.

options.text: Descend LUF438. "LUF438, descend and maintain FL330."
options.feedback: Incorrect. It is poor practice to move an international heavy aircraft at cruise altitude when the climbing aircraft is the conflicting factor.

steps.description: AAL112 levels at FL340. LUF438 passes overhead. The conflict is resolved. AAL112 requests to resume climb.

options.text: Clear AAL112 to climb. "AAL112, climb and maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Correct. The conflict is clear, and the pilot's request can now be safely granted.

options.text: Clear AAL112 with speed. "AAL112, resume normal speed, climb and maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Incorrect. No speed restriction was issued, so 'resume normal speed' is irrelevant.

options.text: Verify traffic. "AAL112, traffic no factor, roger."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is non-standard phraseology and doesn't answer the pilot's request.

options.text: Wait. "AAL112, standby."
options.feedback: Incorrect. There is no reason to delay the climb.

steps.description: LUF438, now past the conflict, requests a descent to FL330 to get out of forecast turbulence.

options.text: Deny. "LUF438, unable, maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Denying a turbulence request without checking traffic is poor service.

options.text: Check traffic below. Sector is clear. "LUF438, descend and maintain FL330."
options.feedback: Correct. The sector is clear, and the descent can be approved.

options.text: Descend with restriction. "LUF438, descend pilot's discretion FL330."
options.feedback: Partial. This is acceptable, but 'descend and maintain' is more direct and standard.

options.id: LUF438, fly heading 260, vectors for ride."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The pilot requested an altitude change, not a vector.

steps.description: LUF438 is level at FL330. AAL112 is level at FL360. Both are approaching the boundary with Toronto Center (CYYZ).

options.text: Initiate data link handoff for LUF438. "LUF438, contact Toronto Center 133.4."
options.feedback: Partial. This is the correct action for LUF438, but AAL112 also needs a handoff.

options.text: Handoff both aircraft in sequence. "AAL112, contact Toronto Center 133.4." ... "LUF438, contact Toronto Center 133.4."
options.feedback: Correct. Handoffs are done sequentially, usually based on proximity to the boundary or altitude (higher first is common).

options.text: Handoff AAL112 only. "AAL112, contact Toronto Center 133.4."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Both aircraft must be handed off.

options.text: Coordinate via data link 'ADC' message for both, then wait for pilot report.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The handoff requires a frequency change instruction to the pilot.

steps.title: Shanwick: Oceanic Reroute (CPDLC)
steps.description: Handle a mid-ocean reroute request from a pilot via CPDLC due to significant turbulence on the organized track.
AFR006 (FL380, M0.84) on NAT Track 'Delta' sends a CPDLC request: 'REQ REROUTE 60NM NORTH OF TRACK DUE TURBC'.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a premature denial.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'STDBY'. Check traffic on parallel Track 'Echo' (60NM north).
options.feedback: Correct. This is the standard procedure. The controller must check for traffic conflicts on the adjacent track.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'DEVIATION 60NM NORTH APPROVED'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is highly dangerous and could cause a collision if Track Echo is in use.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'CLB FL400'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This does not address the pilot's request (reroute) and offers an unsolicited altitude.

steps.description: You check Track 'Echo'. It is active, with traffic at FL380, FL360, and FL340. The requested reroute is impossible at FL380.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE REROUTE DUE TRAFFIC. CLB FL400 APPROVED'.
options.feedback: Partial. This is a possible solution, but it's better to offer the pilot the *reason* and the available alternative in one message.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE FL380 DUE TRACK ECHO. AVAILABLE: 1) MAINTAIN FL380 CURRENT TRACK, 2) REROUTE VIA TRACK ECHO AT FL390'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. FL390 is a westbound level. This is an eastbound track system. Levels are typically FL380, FL360, etc.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE FL380 DUE PARALLEL TRACK IN USE. AVAILABLE FL400 ON CURRENT TRACK. ADVISE.'
options.feedback: Correct. This clearly explains *why* the request is denied (UNABLE FL380 DUE...) and offers the best available alternative (FL400) to mitigate the turbulence.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE REROUTE. MAINTAIN FL380.'
options.feedback: Partial. This is a safe but unhelpful denial. A good controller offers alternatives.

steps.description: The pilot responds via CPDLC: 'REQ CLB FL400'.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'CLIMB TO AND MAINTAIN FL400, REPORT REACHING'.
options.feedback: Correct. This is the standard ICAO clearance for an oceanic climb.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'CLB FL400'.
options.feedback: Partial. This is too brief and lacks the required 'REPORT REACHING' for procedural control.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'WILCO'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. WILCO is a pilot response.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'RADAR CONTACT FL400'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is not radar airspace.

steps.description: An ADS-C message 'LEVEL FL400' is received. The aircraft is approaching the boundary with Gander Oceanic.

options.text: No action needed. Gander will see the ADS-C report.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The handoff is not automatic.

options.text: Acknowledge the level report. Update the strip. Initiate data link handoff to Gander.
options.feedback: Correct. This completes the altitude change loop (acknowledge) and performs the next required action (handoff).

options.text: Call Gander on the tie-line to advise of the altitude change.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is what data link (ADS-C/CPDLC) is designed to replace. It's unnecessary.

options.text: Send CPDLC: 'CONTACT GANDER 131.5'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. Oceanic handoffs are typically via data link or HF, not VHF, unless at the very edge of coverage.

steps.title: Madrid: North/South Crossing Conflict
steps.description: Resolve a high-altitude conflict between a north-south (Europe-Africa) flight and a west-bound (Europe-US) flight.
BAW115 (FL370) is westbound, heading for oceanic airspace. RYR789 (FL380) is southbound, heading for GCCC (Canaries). They will cross in 10 minutes. RYR789's track is 40 degrees offset from BAW115.

options.text: No conflict. They are at different altitudes.
options.feedback: Incorrect. 1000 feet is legal separation, but it's not the only factor. The situation must be monitored.

options.text: Potential conflict. Monitor closely.
options.feedback: Correct. While legally separated, busy crossing points are high-risk. No action is needed *yet*, but it must be monitored.

options.text: Descend BAW115. "BAW115, descend and maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a premature action for a legally separated situation.

options.text: Turn RYR789. "RYR789, turn right heading 200."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Unnecessary vectoring.

steps.description: RYR789 suddenly requests a descent: "Madrid, RYR789, request FL360 due to turbulence."

options.text: Approve. "RYR789, descend and maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This creates an immediate conflict with BAW115 at FL370.

options.text: Deny and inform. "RYR789, UNABLE FL360 due traffic, BAW115, 2 o'clock, 15 miles, FL370."
options.feedback: Correct. This is the only safe response. It denies the request and provides the traffic information as to why.

options.text: Descend BAW115 first. "BAW115, descend and maintain FL350." Then, "RYR789, descend and maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is too slow and complex. It also moves the non-requesting aircraft.

options.text: Offer FL370. "RYR789, UNABLE FL360, FL370 is available."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This creates a level-on-level, non-separated situation with BAW115.

steps.description: RYR789 replies, "Roger, unable, maintaining FL380." Now, BAW115 (FL370) requests a climb: "Madrid, BAW115, request FL390, turbulence."

options.text: Approve. "BAW115, climb and maintain FL390."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This climbs BAW115 *through* RYR789's level (FL380).

options.text: Deny. "BAW115, unable, maintain FL370."
options.feedback: Partial. This is safe but unhelpful.

options.text: Deny and inform, offer later. "BAW115, unable climb due traffic RYR789, 10 o'clock, 10 miles, FL380. Expect climb in 2 minutes."
options.feedback: Correct. This explains the denial, provides the traffic, and manages the pilot's expectations, which is high-level service.

options.text: Turn BAW115. "BAW115, turn left heading 260, then climb FL390."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is inefficient and vectors them off their oceanic track.

steps.description: The aircraft are now past the crossing point. BAW115 is 10 NM past RYR789's track.

options.text: Proactively clear BAW115. "BAW115, traffic no factor, climb and maintain FL390."
options.feedback: Correct. This shows you remembered the pilot's request and are clearing them as soon as it's safe.

options.text: Wait for BAW115 to ask again.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is poor service.

options.text: Clear RYR789 to descend. "RYR789, traffic no factor, descend and maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Partial. This is a good action, but BAW115's pending request is the more immediate item.

options.text: Handoff BAW115 to Santa Maria. "BAW115, contact Santa Maria 127.9."
options.feedback: Incorrect. You must resolve the pending altitude request *before* handoff.

steps.title: Singapore: ADS-C Failure & Procedural Separation
steps.description: Manage an aircraft whose ADS-C and CPDLC connection fails in a procedural, non-radar part of the FIR, requiring a revert to HF and procedural separation.
You receive a 'DATA LINK LOST' alert for QFA12 (FL360) in your procedural sector. Their ADS-C reports stop.

options.text: Do nothing. The system will likely reconnect.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a passive and unsafe assumption.

options.text: Attempt to re-establish CPDLC connection via a 'CONTACT' message.
options.feedback: Partial. This is a good first technical step, but it doesn't address the separation problem.

options.text: Update the flight strip to 'Data Link Failed'. Switch to monitoring HF position reports at the next compulsory reporting point.
options.feedback: Correct. You must immediately note the failure and revert to the backup system, which is procedural control via HF voice reports.

options.text: Vector all other traffic away from QFA12's track.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is an overreaction and would cause massive disruption.

steps.description: QFA12 is due at waypoint 'ANPAG' at 14:30Z. You must ensure procedural separation with UAE44 (FL360), 15 minutes behind QFA12.

options.text: Contact UAE44 (who has a good data link) and issue speed. "UAE44, reduce speed to Mach point eight zero."
options.feedback: Correct. With QFA12's data link down, you can't control them. You must control the aircraft *behind* them to ensure the 15-minute procedural separation is not eroded.

options.text: Contact UAE44 and instruct them to climb. "UAE44, climb and maintain FL380."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This could conflict with other traffic, and the primary separation is longitudinal.

options.text: Call QFA12 on the HF emergency frequency (121.5) and order them to climb.
options.feedback: Incorrect. 121.5 is for emergencies. Their data link failing is not a
situation.

options.text: Assume QFA12 will maintain speed and separation will be fine.
options.feedback: Incorrect. 'Assume' is the most dangerous word in ATC.

steps.description: QFA12 calls on the sector's HF frequency: "Singapore Radio, QFA12, position ANPAG 1430, FL360, estimating 'BETNO' 1510."

options.text: Acknowledge. "QFA12, Singapore, roger."
options.feedback: Partial. This is a weak readback. A full readback is required.

options.text: Scold the pilot. "QFA12, your data link is down, you should have called earlier."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Unprofessional and does not solve the problem.

options.text: Acknowledge and confirm. "QFA12, Singapore copies, ANPAG 1430, FL360, estimating BETNO 1510. Report BETNO."
options.feedback: Correct. This is the standard ICAO procedural readback, confirming the report and giving the next instruction (report at BETNO).

options.text: Give a new clearance. "QFA12, report passing all waypoints."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is an unnecessary increase in pilot workload.

steps.description: With the HF report, you confirm QFA12's estimate. Your speed restriction on UAE44 has maintained 16 minutes' separation.

options.text: Cancel UAE44's speed restriction. "UAE44, resume normal speed."
options.feedback: Correct. Now that positive procedural separation is confirmed via the HF report, the restriction on UAE44 is no longer required.

options.text: Keep the speed restriction on UAE44.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is inefficient and penalizes the aircraft unnecessarily.

options.text: Tell QFA12 to speed up. "QFA12, via HF, increase to Mach point eight two."
options.feedback: Incorrect. You are controlling the aircraft behind, not the one in front.

options.text: Handoff both aircraft to Jakarta. "QFA12, contact Jakarta 132.5." "UAE44, contact Jakarta 132.5."
options.feedback: Incorrect. You must coordinate the HF-only status of QFA12 with Jakarta *before* transfer.

steps.title: ZLA: Handoff and Altitude Discrepancy
steps.description: Handle a handoff from an adjacent center (ZAB) where the aircraft's data block does not match their assigned altitude.
ZAB (Albuquerque) flashes SWA55 at FL370. You accept the handoff. The SWA55 data block now shows 'A370' but 'C380' (Climbing to FL380).

options.text: Do nothing. Assume the data block is correct and they are climbing to FL380.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a discrepancy that must be resolved.

options.text: Call ZAB on the landline. "ZAB, ZLA, check SWA55 altitude. You flashed 370, data block shows climbing to 380."
options.feedback: Correct. The handoff must be verified. This is an inter-center coordination issue.

options.text: Assume ZAB made a mistake and manually change the data block to A370.
options.feedback: Incorrect. Never assume; always verify. Modifying the data block without confirmation is dangerous.

options.text: Wait for SWA55 to check in on your frequency.
options.feedback: Partial. You will do this, but the coordination with ZAB must happen *before* or *during* this to resolve the ambiguity.

steps.description: ZAB confirms, "Sorry, SWA55 was climbing to 380, clearance just given." SWA55 now checks in: "Los Angeles Center, SWA55, level FL370 climbing to FL380."

options.text: Acknowledge. "SWA55, Los Angeles Center, roger."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is not ICAO standard. 'Roger' is weak, and 'radar contact' is missing.

options.text: Acknowledge and verify. "SWA55, Los Angeles Center, radar contact. Confirm climbing to FL380."
options.feedback: Correct. This acknowledges the aircraft, confirms radar identity, and explicitly verifies the climbing altitude, closing the loop on the discrepancy.

options.text: Stop the climb. "SWA55, Los Angeles Center, maintain FL370."
options.feedback: Incorrect. You've already coordinated with ZAB that FL380 is the correct altitude. Stopping them is confusing.

options.text: Ask their altitude. "SWA55, Los Angeles Center, say altitude."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The pilot just reported their altitude. Asking again is redundant.

steps.description: SWA55 is now level at FL380. You see a conflict in 10 minutes with DAL90, also at FL380, merging onto the same airway.

options.text: Descend SWA55. "SWA55, descend and maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Partial. This is a solution, but it's often better to move the aircraft that has not just been re-cleared.

options.text: Turn SWA55. "SWA55, turn right heading 310."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a vector off an airway, which may be inefficient.

options.id: SWA55, reduce speed to Mach point seven eight."
options.feedback: Correct. This is the least disruptive way to manage an in-trail merge conflict. Slowing the trailing aircraft (SWA55) will create space.

options.text: Climb SWA55. "SWA55, climb and maintain FL400."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The pilot just leveled at FL380; another climb is poor service unless requested.

steps.description: The speed restriction has created 20 NM spacing. Both SWA55 and DAL90 are now established on the airway.

options.text: Keep the speed restriction on SWA55.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The restriction is no longer needed and should be removed.

options.text: Cancel the restriction. "SWA55, resume normal speed."
options.feedback: Correct. Once the restriction's purpose is met, it should be canceled to allow for pilot/FMS efficiency.

options.text: Slow down DAL90. "DAL90, reduce speed to Mach point seven eight."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is the opposite of what's needed.

options.text: Vector SWA55. "SWA55, fly heading 300."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The conflict is resolved.

steps.title: ZOB: Data Link Coordination (Toronto)
steps.description: Use data link 'Advance Coordination' (ADC) to send a flight to Toronto Center (CYYZ) at an altitude different from the standing agreement.
ACA880 (FL350) is northbound. The standing agreement with CYYZ is that all traffic on this airway crosses the border at FL350. The pilot requests FL370.

options.text: Approve. "ACA880, climb and maintain FL370."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This violates the standing agreement with CYYZ without coordination.

options.text: Deny. "ACA880, unable FL370, maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Partial. This is safe, but unhelpful. You should attempt to coordinate the pilot's request.

options.text: Acknowledge and initiate coordination. "ACA880, standby." Send an 'ADC' data link message to CYYZ proposing FL370 for ACA880.
options.feedback: Correct. This is the proper procedure. 'Standby' tells the pilot you're working on it, and the ADC message is the formal coordination.

options.text: Call CYYZ on the landline.
options.feedback: Partial. While this works, data link (ADC) is the modern, preferred method and reduces voice calls.

steps.description: CYYZ sends a data link response: 'ACCEPT'.

options.text: Do nothing. The 'ACCEPT' message is for your information only.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The 'ACCEPT' message is the green light to issue the clearance.

options.text: Issue the clearance. "ACA880, climb and maintain FL370."
options.feedback: Correct. Coordination is complete and accepted. The clearance can now be given to the pilot.

options.text: Tell the pilot to call Toronto. "ACA880, contact Toronto Center, they will give you the climb."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is
. You are the controller; you must issue the clearance in your airspace.

options.text: Wait until ACA880 is closer to the border.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The clearance is approved; delaying it serves no purpose.

steps.description: ACA880 is climbing to FL370. An opposite-direction traffic, UAL45, is at FL360. You must ensure separation.

options.text: Issue traffic. "ACA880, traffic 12 o'clock, 10 miles, opposite direction, FL360."
options.feedback: Correct. Even with 1000 feet separation, issuing a traffic advisory on a climbing aircraft to opposite traffic is good procedure.

options.text: Stop ACA880's climb. "ACA880, stop climb FL350."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is an overreaction. 1000 feet is legal separation.

options.text: Descend UAL45. "UAL45, descend and maintain FL340."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Unnecessary movement of an uninvolved aircraft.

options.text: Do nothing. They are 1000 feet apart.
options.feedback: Partial. While legally separated, not issuing a traffic advisory in a climb-through scenario is poor practice.

steps.description: ACA880 reports level at FL370, past the traffic, and approaching the CYYZ border.

options.text: Handoff. "ACA880, contact Toronto Center 133.4."
options.feedback: Correct. The altitude is coordinated, the aircraft is level, and it's at the boundary. This is a standard handoff.

options.text: Call CYYZ again to confirm the handoff.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The 'ACCEPT' data link message and the automated handoff flash are sufficient.

options.text: Wait for the pilot to report the border.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is passive control.

options.text: Descend ACA880 back to FL350. "ACA880, descend and maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The climb to FL370 was approved and coordinated.

steps.title: Shanwick: Loss of Separation (Procedural)
steps.description: Identify and resolve a procedural loss of separation due to a pilot's gross navigational error (GNE).
VIR1 (FL360) on Track 'Bravo' makes an HF call: "Shanwick, VIR1, position 55N 20W at 11:30, FL360, estimating 55N 30W at 12:15." Your data shows they should be at 56N 20W.

options.text: Acknowledge the report. "VIR1, roger, report 55N 30W."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This ignores a 60-mile (1 degree) lateral deviation, which is a GNE.

options.text: Query the pilot. "VIR1, confirm position 55N 20W. Your cleared track is 'Bravo'."
options.feedback: Correct. The first step is to challenge the pilot and confirm the position report, as it indicates a massive error.

options.text: Order them to climb. "VIR1, immediately climb FL380."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a panic reaction without confirming the problem or checking for traffic.

options.text: Manually update the strip. The pilot must be correct.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The FMS/INS is usually correct, but the pilot's data entry can be wrong. The discrepancy IS the problem.

steps.description: VIR1 replies, "Affirm, 55N 20W. We had an FMS input error." This position puts them on Track 'Alpha', which has traffic (BAW212) at FL360, 80 NM ahead.

options.text: Issue new clearance. "VIR1, cleared direct 56N 30W to rejoin Track Bravo, maintain FL360."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is unsafe. It does not resolve the conflict with BAW212, which is now on their *new* track.

options.text: Issue altitude change. "VIR1, immediately descend and maintain FL340. Report reaching."
options.feedback: Correct. The aircraft is on an unauthorized track and in conflict. The only immediate solution is vertical separation.

options.text: Tell them to turn around. "VIR1, turn 180 degrees."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is non-standard and could conflict with traffic behind them.

options.text: Contact BAW212. "BAW212, traffic VIR1, 80 miles behind, deviating, advise."
options.feedback: Incorrect. You must control the deviating aircraft (VIR1), not the compliant one.

steps.description: VIR1 reports 'Reaching FL340'. They are now vertically separated from Track 'Alpha'.

options.text: Now clear them back to their track. "VIR1, cleared direct 56N 40W to rejoin Track Bravo, maintain FL340."
options.feedback: Correct. They are now at a safe altitude. The next step is to get them back on *a* cleared route, and rejoining their original track is the most logical.

options.text: Let them continue on Track 'Alpha' at FL340.
options.feedback: Partial. This is safe, but it's not their cleared route. It's better to get them back on track.

options.text: Clear them to climb back to FL360.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This would put them back in conflict with Track 'Alpha'.

options.text: Ask them for their intentions. "VIR1, say intentions."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The controller must provide the clearance, not the pilot.

steps.description: VIR1 is established on the new clearance, maintaining FL340, and rejoining Track 'Bravo'.

options.text: File a report. No further action needed.
options.feedback: Partial. A report is mandatory, but you must also coordinate.

options.text: Coordinate the new altitude (FL340) with Gander (the next sector) via data link or voice.
options.feedback: Correct. The aircraft will now be at a non-standard altitude for this track. The next center MUST be advised of the change.

options.text: Clear VIR1 to climb to FL360 once past the Track 'Alpha' traffic.
options.feedback: Partial. This is a good idea, but the *mandatory* next step is coordinating the non-standard level with Gander.

options.text: Forget the incident. The pilot corrected.
options.feedback: Incorrect. A GNE (Gross Navigational Error) is a serious incident that requires reporting and coordination.

steps.title: Madrid: Oceanic Clearance Data Link Error
steps.description: Resolve a discrepancy where the Oceanic Clearance (OCL) received by the pilot via data link does not match the domestic flight plan.

TAP123 (FL350) is approaching the oceanic boundary. Their flight plan shows OEP 'SONNI' at FL350. The pilot calls: "Madrid, TAP123, our CPDLC Oceanic Clearance shows OEP 'RONKO' at FL370. Please advise."

options.text: Tell the pilot to follow the OCL. "TAP123, roger, follow the CPDLC clearance."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is a major discrepancy. The domestic controller cannot accommodate a different track and level without coordination.

options.text: Tell the pilot the OCL is wrong. "TAP123, your clearance is incorrect. Standby." Call Santa Maria to coordinate.
options.feedback: Correct. The pilot has identified a conflict. The controller must stop, acknowledge, and coordinate with the OACC (Santa Maria) to fix it.

options.text: Re-clear the pilot. "TAP123, disregard that, cleared direct SONNI, maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Incorrect. This tells the pilot to ignore a clearance from the OACC, which is a major procedural violation.

options.text: Tell the pilot to call Santa Maria.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The aircraft is still in your airspace; it's your responsibility to coordinate.

steps.description: You call Santa Maria, who states the 'RONKO' clearance was for a different flight. They will issue a new OCL to TAP123 via data link.

options.text: Advise the pilot. "TAP123, Santa Maria made an error. Expect a new CPDLC clearance shortly. Maintain FL350 and track for SONNI."
options.feedback: Correct. This informs the pilot of the situation, tells them what to expect (new OCL), and confirms their current clearance.

options.text: Do nothing. Wait for the pilot to get the new clearance.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The pilot is waiting for instructions from you.

options.text: Vector the pilot. "TAP123, fly heading 270."
options.feedback: Incorrect. There is no need to vector. The pilot is on the correct track.

options.text: Give the clearance yourself. "TAP123, cleared to KJFK via SONNI, FL350..."
options.feedback: Incorrect. You cannot issue an oceanic clearance; only the OACC can.

steps.description: TAP123 calls back: "Madrid, we have the new OCL via CPDLC. Cleared via SONNI, FL350, Mach point eight zero."

options.text: Acknowledge. "TAP123, roger."
options.feedback: Partial. This is a weak acknowledgment.

options.text: Verify and handoff. "TAP123, that is correct. Contact Santa Maria 127.9."
options.feedback: Correct. The domestic controller's job is to verify the OCL matches the flight plan. It now does. The aircraft can be handed off.

options.text: Ask them to read it all back.
options.feedback: Incorrect. A full readback is not required, as the pilot is just confirming the new clearance matches the domestic plan.

options.text: Tell them to maintain FL350. "TAP123, roger, maintain FL350."
options.feedback: Incorrect. The final handoff instruction is missing.

steps.description: The aircraft is 5 minutes from the boundary and has been handed off to Santa Maria.

options.text: This is a 'controller action' step. No action is required. Monitor the transfer.
options.feedback: Correct. The conflict is resolved, the clearance is verified, and the handoff is complete. The controller's job is to monitor the aircraft until it leaves the frequency.

options.text: Call Santa Maria again to 'make sure'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. Unnecessary voice call.

options.text: Call the pilot back. "TAP123, confirm you are talking to Santa Maria."
options.feedback: Incorrect. Unnecessary. The data block will show the frequency change.

options.text: File a report against the pilot.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The pilot did the correct thing by reporting the discrepancy.

steps.title: Singapore: Multi-FIR Weather Deviation
steps.description: Manage a weather deviation that crosses multiple FIR boundaries (Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta) using data link.
SIA45 (FL370) is on the boundary with Kuala Lumpur (WMFC). Pilot sends CPDLC: 'REQ DEVIATION 40NM LEFT DUE WX'. This deviation will cross into WMFC, then into Jakarta (WIIF) airspace.

options.text: Approve. Send CPDLC: 'DEVIATION 40NM LEFT APPROVED'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This approves a deviation into two other FIRs without coordination.

options.text: Deny. Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE DEVIATION'.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is unsafe for a weather request.

options.text: Acknowledge and coordinate. Send CPDLC: 'STDBY'. Initiate ADC data link coordination with WMFC and WIIF.
options.feedback: Correct. This is a complex coordination that *must* be approved by all affected FIRs.

options.description: WMFC replies 'ACCEPT'. WIIF (Jakarta) replies 'UNABLE DUE TRAFFIC'.

options.text: Approve a partial deviation. Send CPDLC: 'DEVIATION UP TO 20NM LEFT APPROVED. UNABLE 40NM DUE JAKARTA TRAFFIC.'
options.feedback: Correct. This provides the pilot with the maximum available, coordinated deviation, and explains the restriction.

options.text: Deny the whole request. Send CPDLC: 'UNABLE DEVIATION DUE JAKARTA TRAFFIC'.
options.feedback: Partial. This is safe, but the pilot could have been given *some* deviation.

options.text: Tell WMFC to coordinate with WIIF.
options.feedback: Incorrect. You are the controlling authority; it's your responsibility.

options.text: Approve the full deviation anyway. "DEVIATION 40NM LEFT APPROVED".
options.feedback: Incorrect. This ignores Jakarta's denial and is extremely dangerous.

options.description: SIA45 replies 'WILCO' and begins the 20NM deviation. Jakarta (WIIF) now sends a data link message: 'TRAFFIC CLEAR, SIA45 MAY DEVIATE AS REQUESTED'.

options.text: Do nothing. The pilot is already deviating.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The pilot is restricted to 20NM. You now have new information.

options.text: Proactively update the pilot. Send CPDLC: 'JAKARTA TRAFFIC NOW NO FACTOR. DEVIATION UP TO 40NM LEFT NOW APPROVED.'
options.feedback: Correct. This shows excellent situational awareness, closing the loop with the pilot and giving them the deviation they originally needed.

options.text: Wait for the pilot to ask again.
options.feedback: Incorrect. This is poor, reactive service.

options.text: Tell the pilot to contact Jakarta.
options.feedback: Incorrect. They are still in your airspace, and you are coordinating on their behalf.

options.description: SIA45 completes the deviation and sends CPDLC: 'RESUMING OWN NAVIGATION DIRECT VPL'. The aircraft is now in WMFC airspace, but you are still the controlling authority.

options.text: Acknowledge and handoff. Send CPDLC: 'PROCEED DIRECT VPL'. Then: 'CONTACT KUALA LUMPUR 132.8'.
options.feedback: Correct. You re-establish the route, then handoff the aircraft to the next FIR.

options.text: Handoff only. Send CPDLC: 'CONTACT KUALA LUMPUR 132.8'.
options.feedback: Partial. You should first acknowledge/approve their 'resuming navigation' message.

options.text: Acknowledge only. Send CPDLC: 'PROCEED DIRECT VPL'.
options.feedback: Partial. This is good, but the handoff is now required as they are established and in WMFC airspace.

options.text: Wait for them to be back in your airspace.
options.feedback: Incorrect. The handoff should occur at the FIR boundary.
